item.description: Johanna Larsson is a software engineer, manager, writer, speaker. With over 14 years of experience in software development and management, she has worked with clients from various industries, including finance, healthcare, and education. She is passionate about creating innovative solutions that solve real-world problems. She is also an advocate for diversity and inclusion in the tech industry. She believes that technology can be a force for good and strives to make a positive impact in the world. She is committed to using her skills and expertise to create a better future for all.

item.title: Tim Cook vs. Steve Jobs
item.description: On Friday I published a glowing book review of Apple in China by Patrick McGee. Coincidentally, on the same day UnHerd published an article by Patrick McGee, Time is running out for Tim Cook: Apple lacks strategic vision. I continue to admire McGee‚Äôs reporting, continue to recommend his book, and this new article hasn‚Äôt changed my mind about that. However, reporters who have made a name for themselves have a tendency to want to become commentators, to add their opinions to their factual reporting. In my own opinion, the opinions of reporters are no better than anyone else‚Äôs opinion. The ability to get quality news scoops doesn‚Äôt automatically make someone superior at analyzing the implications of that news. Another example of this phenomenon is Mark Gurman of Bloomberg, a prolific source of Apple leaks, unparalleled in tech reporting history; I salute his uncanny prowess as a reporter. Nonetheless, his opinions are pedestrian at best, ill-advised at worst, and I find it regrettable that Gurman‚Äôs articles sometimes muddy the distinction between his leaks and his opinions.

item.title: OpenAI Needs Adult Supervision
item.description: Whether from ambition, arrogance or lack of discipline, OpenAI is in trouble today. The company must overcome significant internal and market issues if it is to survive the coming years. A handful of fault‚Äëlines will determine the outcome. Any structural weakness surrounding these foundational elements of AI‚Äôs present and future could burst ambitions that may very well have already reached bubble territory.

item.title: üò∂‚Äçüå´Ô∏è Controlling the weather üå¶Ô∏è ¬ª Firesphere.dev
item.description:
It started with our Mitsubishi heatpump. Someone on the internet had found a way to control it via Home Assistant. Sadly, this heatpump broke down in April... In July (yes, 10 weeks later!) we got a new one. A Panasonic this time.
A side-note, I recently started working at the New Zealand Meteorological Service (MetService)... So the title is a double joke...

item.title: Even happier eyeballs
item.description: Back in 2012, the Happy Eyeballs RFC 6555 was published. It details how a sensible Internet client should proceed when connecting to a server. It basically goes like this: Give the IPv6 attempt priority, then with a delay start a separate IPv4 connection in parallel with the IPv6 one; then use the connection that succeeds ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Even happier eyeballs ‚Üí

item.title: What's New in C# 14: User-Defined Compound Assignments
item.description: C# 14, coming with .NET 10, introduces user-defined compound assignments. It allows for the creation of more efficient assignment operators, preventing unnecessary object creation. Discover how to implement and use this new feature, and learn about the potential pitfalls to watch out for.
